newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: NUM, Northam to meet on wage deadlock.
newsitem.headline: NUM, Northam to meet on wage deadlock.

text.p: The National Union of Mineworkers (NUM) and Northam Platinum Mines Ltd management will meet on Monday to seek a settlement to avert a strike, a union official said.

"Management has requested a meeting in the next hour or so. And we don't know what they want and we are hoping they have something to offer," NUM regional coordinator Mahlakeng Mahlakeng told Reuters by telephone from Rustenburg.
Some 96.8 percent of the NUM's 3,300 members at Northam voted in favour of strike action last Wednesday.
The union and management at the mine, owned by Gold Fields of South Africa Ltd, reached deadlock over wage increases on September 26.
The union had initially demanded a 15 percent pay hike but was prepared to accept management's offer of 10 percent.
NUM said the point of contention was wage parity as Northam's minimum wage of around 556 rand was well below that of other mines.
Mahlakeng said the union and mine management met on Saturday but no progress was made.
"We met on Saturday but obviously as a result of the last minute request by management, we felt that it might be useful to give them a hearing (on Monday)," he said.
Northam produced 75,365 ounces of precious metals in concentrates in the three months to September.
The mine recorded a net loss before capital spending of 7.39 million rand in the September quarter after turning in a profit of 8.17 million in the previous quarter.
Analysts said the mine would be hard pressed to deal with a strike by almost two-thirds of its workforce who belong to the NUM.
